text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Some of the distressed banks which were unable to meet a March 31 deadline to recapitalise or be liquidated and in which investors have shown serious interest are likely to get another period of grace before the hammer falls on them.

- Nigeria starts negotiations with World Bank to take an $18 million loan due to it for various environmental protection projects, says director-general of federal environmental protection agency, Adegoke Adegoroye.
- Seven ships expected at Lagos port this week with 35,000 metric tonnes of cement.
- Nigeria's privately owned Peak Petroleum Industries Ltd secures joint venture deal with U.S. firm NTI Resources to explore and produce oil and gas in Nigerian offshore wells.
- Four firms start test-run operations at export processing zone in Calabar in the southeastern Nigeria.
- Central bank formally loses its autonomy with publication of decree under which it reports to finance ministry.
- State oil firm NNPC, faced with acute shortages, rations fuel supply to Lagos depots.
- Transfer of accounts of government companies to commercial banks from central bank is suspended in order to stem high level of money in circulation, sources say.
- Nigerian Railway Corporation is set to spend 2.64 billion naira to install micro-wave digital communication system, says transport minister Major-General Ibrahim Gumel.
- Members of opposition NADECO group on exile in London are stranded because British government has not acted on their two-year-old requests for asylum.
- Security agents may raid communities in search of arms and ammunition in the midwestern oil town of Warri where Shell oil company workers were held hostage last week.
- Sources say state oil firm NNPC is considering Paris, rather Vienna for its European coordinating office, which was closed down in London two weeks ago.
